body: Embattled Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca announced his plans to retire at the end of the month at a press conference Tuesday morning.
title: LA County Sheriff Lee Baca announces plans to retire
caption: Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference Jan. 7, 2014 where he announced his plans to retire.

body: The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed five cases that charge 18 current or former members of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department with a wide range of crimes — 38 charges in all. Sheriff Lee Baca called it a "sad day" and added that the department has been fully cooperative with the investigation.
title: 18 current and former LA Sheriff officers charged in jail abuse case
caption: Los Angeles Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference responding to the F.B.I. arrests of 17 Los Angeles sheriff's deputies.

body: In an unusual decision, a federal jury in Los Angeles has found Sheriff Lee Baca personally liable for the excessive use of force against an inmate at Men’s Central Jail. Baca will personally pay $100,000 in punitive damages.
title: LA Sheriff Baca financially liable in jail inmate abuse case

body: Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca distanced himself from Yor Health, a health products company, whose products he promoted in online videos. Yor Health donated $1,000 to Baca's election campaign in 2010 and reimbursed him for travel expenses from one speaking engagement.
title: LA County sheriff Baca cuts ties with health company after ethics concerns arise
caption: A screenshot from ABC7's report on Baca's relationship with Yor Health, a health products company, whose products he promoted in online videos. Yor Health donated $1,000 to Baca's election campaign in 2010 and reimbursed him for travel expenses from one speaking engagement.

body: Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca touted lower crime rates and his charitable giving in an appearance at the Sherman Oaks Homeowners Association Thursday night, while skirting the biggest problem facing his department: two federal investigations into his sprawling jail system, which houses nearly 20,000 inmates.
title: Sheriff Baca mum on federal jail inquiries, boasts lower crime rates
caption: Sheriff Lee Baca insisted his department is in good shape, despite two federal investigations into his jail system.

body: Paul Tanaka, the longtime number two man in the LA County Sheriff's Department, becomes an outspoken critic of the department.
title: Paul Tanaka offers harsh criticism of Baca
caption: Undersherrif Paul Tanaka prepares to testify in front of the Citizens Commission on Jail Violence on Friday, July 27, 2012. The commission was formed by the LA County Board of Supervisors to investigate allegations of abuse at county jails.

body: Baca's Twitter arrival comes as the Sheriff’s Department struggles with grim publicity over the last year—from deputy abuse of inmates in the county jails, to off-duty deputies behaving badly, to accusations of department nepotism.
title: Facing onslaught of bad publicity, Baca joins Twitter
caption: LA County Sheriff Lee Baca has joined Twitter and his now writing a blog on the LA Sheriff's Department website.

body: Although under fire for jailhouse abuses, Baca, was picked as the nation's Sheriff of the Year.
title: Baca named national 'Sheriff of the Year'

body: Seven Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies have been notified that the department intends to fire them for being members of a secret law enforcement clique that celebrated shootings and branded its members with matching tattoos, the Los Angeles Times reported.
title: After scandal, Baca moves to fire deputies in Jump Out Boys clique

body: Under mounting political pressure to reform L.A. County jails, and after the board put in place a compliance monitor to track his progress. Baca said he would implement the new reforms, with or without crucial funding, and that a new force policy will be released in January.
title: Baca responds to criticism over jail violence
caption: Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference at the Los Angeles Sheriffs Department June 8, 2007 in Monterey Park, California.

body: Sheriff Lee Baca ordered the recall of about 200 official-looking Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department badges and ID cards that were distributed to local politicians. The decision to round up the badges came weeks after the FBI arrested three Cudahy officials on bribery charges.
title: Baca recalls 200 false badges and identification cards handed out to politicians
caption: The U.S. attorney's office released this photo it says was taken at a Cudahy night club showing an unidentified woman wearing Councilman Osvaldo Conde's sheriff's badge as she holds his gun in one hand and his bodyguard's in another.

body: The U.S. Supreme Court turned down L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca’s petition to stop an inmate from suing him over a jail stabbing, setting the stage for the lawsuit to go forward.
title: Jail-stabbing suit against Sheriff Lee Baca moves forward
caption: Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca in 2010

body: LA County sheriff's detectives launch probe into what appears to be a secret deputy clique within the department's elite gang unit, an investigation triggered by the discovery of a document suggesting the group embraces shootings as a badge of honor, the Los Angeles Times reported.
title: Secret clique in L.A. County sheriff's gang unit probed
caption: A tattoo featured on a number of sheriff's clique members allegedly glamorized jailhouse violence

body: Sheriff Lee Baca briefly considered closing part of Men's Central Jail in downtown Los Angeles after a federal investigation was announced into alleged deputy brutality in L.A. county jails.
title: Baca considers shutting part of Men's Central Jail after abuse allegations
caption: Los Angeles County Men's Central Jail

body: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a federal civil rights lawsuit that accuses Sheriff Lee Baca of failing to stop a “pattern and practice of deputy-on-inmate violence” inside L.A. County jails.
title: ACLU files federal lawsuit against Sheriff Baca over jail abuse
caption: L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca conducts an inspection of Men's Central Jail in Downtown Los Angeles in this photo from December 2011.

body: Immigrant rights groups sue Baca in an effort to force him to hand over information about his cooperation with federal immigration authorities.
title: Immigrants rights groups sue LA County sheriff Baca

body: Baca said he'll release non-violent inmates with minimal criminal histories earlier than planned to help the county address a $400 million budget shortfall.
title: Baca seeks early release of inmates

body: Elected by the citizens of Los Angeles County, Sheriff Lee Baca began leading the largest Sheriff's Department in the United States and supervising more than 13,000 sworn and civilian personnel.
title: Sheriff Baca sworn in as LA County's 30th Sheriff

body: Lee Baca saw himself as an advocate of education. He earned his Bachelor's degree in 1971 from California State University, Los Angeles, a Master of Public Administration in 1973, and later received his Doctorate of Public Administration in 1993 from the University of Southern California School of Policy, Planning, and Development.
title: Baca graduates from USC

body: After serving as commander of numerous stations, Lee Baca was promoted to the rank of Chief by then Sheriff Sherman Block.
title: Baca promoted to Chief Deputy

body: Early on in his career, Baca worked in custody, recruitment, on patrol on the streets of East Los Angeles and as instructor at the Sheriff's Academy. Throughout his time at the sheriff's department, he rose through the ranks — from commander all the way to chief in 1992.
title: Lee Baca sworn in as a deputy sheriff trainee at the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department
Baca enters the United States Marine Corps Reserves
